At-a-Glance: Amitraz-based products remain effective varroacides in many regions, but resistance pressure grows with overuse. Stewardship means label-compliant dosing, full-course treatments, rotation, and verification with counts.
Why it Matters: Losing a mode of action narrows the toolbox and increases winter losses. Responsible use preserves efficacy and protects bees and markets.
Step-by-Step: Confirm thresholds; remove honey supers if required; place strips per brood size; respect duration and temperature limits; remove on schedule; repeat counts post-treatment. Rotate with non-amitraz methods in subsequent cycles (thymol, OA with brood breaks, biotechnical controls). Record batch numbers and dates.
Seasonality & Climate: Often used post-harvest in late summer/early autumn. Avoid extremes outside label ranges and adapt colony ventilation to prevent stress.
Common Pitfalls: Under-dosing, leaving strips in too long, or repeating back-to-back seasons. Skipping verification counts hides emerging resistance.
Tools & Materials: Approved amitraz product, timer/calendar, mite sampling kit, records for audits and future planning.
